item.title: @dalton: @mlv @oderwat there are existing systems that use similar verification mechanisms, ie google webmaster tools and Pinterest
item.description: @mlv @oderwat there are existing systems that use similar verification mechanisms, ie google webmaster tools and Pinterest

item.title: @dalton: @rel @duerig @nitinkhanna There's basic user search in the API http://developers.app.net/docs/resources/user/lookup/#search-for-users We might expand search in the API, but am unsure how/when. Even if, I still think there is a place for 3rd party search
item.description: @rel @duerig @nitinkhanna There's basic user search in the API http://developers.app.net/docs/resources/user/lookup/#search-for-users We might expand search in the API, but am unsure how/when. Even if, I still think there is a place for 3rd party search

item.title: @dalton: @mrgan @dwineman I think a prospect theorist would argue that Loss Aversion is a more powerful determinant of behaviors than the what the actual money at stake is http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Loss_aversion
item.description: @mrgan @dwineman I think a prospect theorist would argue that Loss Aversion is a more powerful determinant of behaviors than the what the actual money at stake is http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Loss_aversion

item.title:
@dalton: @mrgan I googled for "prospect theory pricing strategy" and this was the first result http://www.insead.edu/facultyresearch/research/doc.cfm?did=1726
One summary is people are afraid of paying too much if they expect discounts in future due to "anchoring"
item.description: @mrgan I googled for "prospect theory pricing strategy" and this was the first result http://www.insead.edu/facultyresearch/research/doc.cfm?did=1726 One summary is people are afraid of paying too much if they expect discounts in future due to "anchoring"

item.title: @dalton: @mrgan I witnessed a lot of justifications/ideas re:music pricing in the digital music space. The truth is people like http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniel_Kahneman are right, textbook microeconomics is wrong... people are often economically "irrational"
item.description: @mrgan I witnessed a lot of justifications/ideas re:music pricing in the digital music space. The truth is people like http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniel_Kahneman are right, textbook microeconomics is wrong... people are often economically "irrational"
